channel.title: WSJ.com: World News
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: How Russia’s Call for Peace Talks Turned Into a Diplomatic Defeat for Putin
item.description: Germany, France, the U.K. and Poland outmaneuvered the Kremlin by persuading Ukraine’s Zelensky to accept Trump’s cease-fire demand. Russia’s leader balked.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cullison

item.title: In Gaza, Long-Suffering Palestinians Are Directing Their Anger at Hamas
item.description: More people who are tired of the hunger, sleeplessness and ever-present threat of Israeli airstrikes are demonstrating against the militant group
item.dc:creator: Abeer Ayyoub

item.title: Trump’s Middle East Tour Boosts Arab States at Israel’s Expense
item.description: White House disagreements with Israel have more to do with the president’s agenda than a long-term divergence, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Kalin

item.title: Israel Expands Gaza Offensive and Strikes Houthis in Yemen
item.description: The Israeli military said it struck the Hodeidah and Salif ports in Yemen, in an attack that came after President Trump wrapped up a trip to the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Anat Peled

item.title: ICC Chief Prosecutor to Go on Leave Until Sexual Misconduct Probe Is Complete
item.description: The Journal reported last week that an aide to Karim Khan told investigators he had forcible sexual intercourse with her on multiple occasions.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Dalton

item.title: China Loosens Grip on Magnet Exports, Relieving Carmakers
item.description: Beijing’s control of rare-earth minerals gives it leverage over U.S. during trade tensions.
item.dc:creator: Raffaele Huang

item.title: Russia-Ukraine Peace Talks Fail to Make Major Headway After Russia Demands More Land
item.description: The two countries, after holding their first direct peace talks in three years, achieved little progress but agreed to swap 1,000 prisoners from each side and to continue contacts toward an eventual cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: Yaroslav Trofimov

item.title: He Calls Them Handsome, Attractive, Tough: Trump’s Bromance With Arab Leaders
item.description: The U.S. president has used a trip to the Middle East to strengthen ties with the Arab world.
item.dc:creator: Alex Leary

item.title: Trump Says U.S., Iran Close to Nuclear Deal
item.description: Oil prices fell as investors anticipated that any deal would entail easing sanctions on Iranian crude exports.
item.dc:creator: Benoit Faucon

item.title: Trump Addresses Troops at U.S. Base That Undergirds Qatar Ties
item.description: Al Udeid air base has enabled the U.S. to project power across the Middle East for more than 20 years.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Kalin

item.title: He Was Undocumented for 30 Years. Then Trump’s Deportations Started.
item.description: Ah Sahm Dawson, a former child soldier who lived in limbo in New York for decades, was sent back to Myanmar in April.
item.dc:creator: Liyan Qi

item.title: EU Wants More in U.S. Trade Deal Than U.K. or China Got
item.description: EU officials want a trade deal with the U.S. that sees a larger reduction in tariffs than negotiations with the U.K. and China have so far yielded.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Probe Details Final Moments on Bayesian Superyacht, Links Giant Mast to Tragedy
item.description: Investigators say the large mast of a yacht owned by the family of British tech mogul Mike Lynch left it vulnerable to high winds.
item.dc:creator: Max Colchester

item.title: How Qatar Spent Billions to Gain Influence in the U.S.
item.description: The tiny Gulf state has showered money on the U.S.’s military and universities, giving it outsize geopolitical clout.
item.dc:creator: Joel Schectman

item.title: Can a School Play Be a Threat to the State? Kenya’s Leaders Seem to Think So
item.description: President William Ruto and his former party chief have clashed over “Echoes of War” and its themes of a worsening generational divide.
item.dc:creator: Caroline Kimeu

item.title: Trump Meets New Syrian Leader After Announcing End of Sanctions
item.description: Trump later heaped praise on the president, calling him a ‘tough guy,’ and urged Ahmed al-Sharaa to normalize relations with Israel.
item.dc:creator: Alex Leary

item.title: Former Chinese Chip Boss Gets Suspended Death Sentence in Corruption Case
item.description: Zhao Weiguo is the former chairman of a once-highflying semiconductor firm that Beijing backed as part of a push to catch up with the West on technological capabilities.
item.dc:creator: Chun Han Wong

item.title: Germany Foils Alleged Russian Plot to Mail Incendiary Devices
item.description: Police detained three men suspected of planning to mail packages laden with explosives in a Russian-sponsored act of sabotage.
item.dc:creator: Bertrand Benoit

item.title: Prime Minister Carney Says Canada Can Emerge As Energy Superpower
item.description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney said he’s willing to amend federal rules that may pose headwinds toward getting energy projects built and capitalize on the country’s abundance of natural resources.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: José Mujica, Marxist Guerrilla Who Became Popular President of Uruguay, Dies at 89
item.description: The militant-turned-politician was an icon of the left in Latin America.
item.dc:creator: Juan Forero

item.title: British Police Investigate Fires at Properties Linked to Prime Minister
item.description: British counterterrorism police are probing a string of suspected arson attacks on two properties linked to Prime Minister Keir Starmer.
item.dc:creator: Max Colchester

item.title: China Exults in Trump’s Tariff Pullback
item.description: The agreement was cheered in Beijing as vindication for Xi Jinping and his defiant response to President Trump’s trade war.
item.dc:creator: Jason Douglas

item.title: Trump Is Giving Refugee Status to White South Africans—but Many Don’t Want to Come
item.description: Relative wealth and generations of history dissuade many Afrikaners from claiming Trump’s offer; ‘This is my country.’
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Wexler

item.title: China Is Building Megaports in South America to Feed Its Need for Crops
item.description: The trade war has heightened China’s need to develop gateways to import the continent’s soybeans, corn and other foodstuffs that are the only viable alternative supply to U.S. exports.
item.dc:creator: Samantha Pearson

item.title: U.K. Plans to Tighten Rules After Record Influx of Migrants
item.description: Britain’s government said a record influx of foreigners since Brexit had done little to energize the economy.
item.dc:creator: Bertrand Benoit

item.title: Pope Leo Seeks to Balance Francis’ Inclusive Approach With Tradition
item.description: The U.S.-born pope has signaled he will continue his predecessor’s work, but shows deference to tradition, too.
item.dc:creator: Margherita Stancati

item.title: The Underground Hunt for Mexico’s Most Wanted Drug Kingpin
item.description: Iván Archivaldo Guzmán evaded capture using tactics he learned from his father, Sinaloa cartel founder Joaquín “El Chapo” Guzmán.
item.dc:creator: José de Córdoba

item.title: India, Pakistan Cease-Fire Brokered by U.S. Appears to Hold
item.description: The neighbors had agreed to a full and immediate cease-fire in the worst violence between them for more than two decades.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Ward

item.title: Russia and North Korea Turn Their War Alliance Into a Propaganda Tool
item.description: The two countries are producing a new wave of content to exalt their partnership in the conflict in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Dasl Yoon

item.title: Pope Leo XIV’s Years in Peru Reveal a Priest Focused on His Flock
item.description: “Monseñor Robert” helped the poor, trekked into the Andes and spread his faith. “He always provided words of hope.”
item.dc:creator: Juan Forero

item.title: Are India and Pakistan at Risk of War? Here’s What We Know
item.description: The latest on the confrontation between the nuclear-armed neighbors over the disputed Muslim-majority region of Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: Shan Li

item.title: What to Watch During the U.S.-China Talks This Weekend
item.description: U.S. and Chinese officials began talks in Geneva on Saturday, setting the stage for a potential thawing of trade relations between the world’s two largest economies.
item.dc:creator: Lingling Wei

item.title: Taiwan’s New Strategy: Make China Fear the Pain of an Invasion
item.description: Taiwan’s so-called porcupine strategy aims to deter a Chinese invasion—or at least stall it until U.S. support arrives.
item.dc:creator: Joyu Wang

item.title: China Struggles With Persistent Disinflationary Pressures as Tariffs Bite
item.description: The consumer-price index declined 0.1% from a year earlier in April, matching the fall seen the prior month and marking a third straight month of drops.

item.title: China Sends Xi’s Security Czar to Trade Talks With U.S.
item.description: The Chinese leader’s decision to send Wang Xiaohong to Geneva suggests fentanyl will play a key role in this weekend’s high-stake talks.
item.dc:creator: Brian Schwartz

item.title: Who Joined Putin in Moscow to Celebrate Victory Day
item.description: More than 20 world leaders gathered in Red Square to mark the 80th anniversary of the victory over Nazi Germany.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Grove

item.title: Key Player in Russian Oil Trading Hit by U.K. Sanctions
item.description: The U.K. sanctioned Etibar Eyyub, a vital figure in Russia’s oil trade, stepping up economic pressure on Moscow to strengthen Ukraine’s hand in peace negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Joe Wallace

item.title: Men Found Guilty of Felling Famous Tree in ‘Moronic Mission’ That Gripped U.K.
item.description: The pair’s destruction of the beloved Sycamore Gap tree stoked nationwide anger and a criminal investigation.
item.dc:creator: Alistair MacDonald

item.title: Putin Parades China, North Korea Ties in Victory Day Show of Force
item.description: Moscow used a World War II commemoration to signal to Washington that Russia can be a helpful ally—or a fearsome foe.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Grove

item.title: How Putin Keeps Russia’s Battle-Hardened Veterans on His Side
item.description: A growing crop of Russian soldiers have been tapped to fill a wave of government positions after serving in Ukraine, raising the prestige of military service and encouraging more people to enlist.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Luxmoore

item.title: India Says It Intercepted Missiles and Drones Launched by Pakistan
item.description: The two nuclear powers accused each other of drone attacks on military targets as tensions between these neighboring nations rise.
item.dc:creator: Corinne Abrams

item.title: BOE Set For Modest Rate Cuts As Inflation Stays High, NIESR Says
item.description: Inflation is likely to remain stubbornly high this year, the National Institute of Economic and Social Research said as it cut is 2025 growth forecast for the U.K.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: A Battlefield Death That Spelled the End for Russia’s Opposition
item.description: Ildar Dadin spent years arguing that nonviolent resistance was the best way to unseat Putin, until he took up arms against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Luxmoore

item.title: ‘Trump With a Pint’: How Nigel Farage Is Upending British Politics
item.description: The populist politician’s Reform UK party is soaring in the polls—and doing better at the ballot box—as voters lose patience with slow economic growth and high immigration.
item.dc:creator: Max Colchester

item.title: JD Vance Sees an India That America Can Work With
item.description: The vice president says India and the U.S. are making progress in trade talks.
item.dc:creator: Shan Li

item.title: India Has a Golden Opportunity to Capture U.S. Business From China
item.description: The world’s most populous nation has long trailed not just China but also smaller countries with nimbler governments.
item.dc:creator: Tripti Lahiri

item.title: Attacks on Darfur Relief Camps Threaten Bloody New Chapter in War
item.description: Fears are growing that a rebel militia is using violence to consolidate control in the famine-stricken region of Sudan.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: In the Other Gaza, Trump’s War on Waste Baffles Mozambique
item.description: The White House claimed U.S. aid workers shipped 3.3 billion condoms to Hamas. They didn’t.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Phillips

item.title: Al Qaeda Punctures Kenya’s Dreams for an Indian Ocean Trade Hub
item.description: Militants based next door in Somalia have stalled the $25 billion plan for an economic corridor across Kenya’s impoverished north.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Phillips

item.title: Modi Positions India as Ally in Trump’s Illegal-Immigration Fight
item.description: India’s leader has supported the deportation of Indian citizens as New Delhi looks to safeguard U.S. relations and protect H-1B visas.
item.dc:creator: Tripti Lahiri

item.title: This Indian Festival Hosts More Pilgrims Than the Population of the U.S.
item.description: At least 400 million people are estimated to have attended the event, believed to be at least two millennia old and now drawing to a close.
item.dc:creator: Shan Li

item.title: Families Battle Tech Giants as Australia Pushes for an Under-16 Social-Media Ban
item.description: The proposal marks the latest effort by political leaders worldwide to regulate children’s use of platforms, amid concerns that it is harming their mental health.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney

item.title: ‘We’ve Got to Kill’: Inside New Zealand’s Mission to Wipe Out Predators
item.description: Scientists debate whether a multibillion-dollar plan to eliminate invasive animals by 2050 is feasible.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney

item.title: France’s Macron Tries to Quell New Caledonia Riots With Globe-Crossing Trip
item.description: The French leader said he is open to suspending a voting-rights bill that sparked the riots once order is restored on the archipelago and talks resume between rival factions.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Meichtry

item.title: France Rushes Reinforcements to Riot-Stricken New Caledonia
item.description: Unrest in the overseas territory could derail President Emmanuel Macron’s efforts to restore French influence in the Indo-Pacific region.
item.dc:creator: Rhiannon Hoyle

item.title: Australia to Boost Defense Spending Amid U.S.-China Tensions
item.description: Australia is boosting its defense budget and rethinking its defense plans as strategic competition between the U.S. and China heats up in the Indo-Pacific region.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney
